I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT  
 
1.  The Supporting Fourth Primary Education Development Program (PEDP4) will support 
Bangladesh’s  primary  education  system  covering  all  children  from  pre-primary  to  grade  5 
nationwide.1 The program builds on the achievements of previous programs with a stronger focus 
on strengthening quality of education and enhancing institutional management. The program 
aligns with the government’s Seventh Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020, and the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy for Bangladesh, 2016–2020.2 The impact of the program 
is strengthened human capital formation. The outcome will be improved quality and equity of 
primary education for all children from pre-primary to grade 5. The program has three outputs; (i) 
quality  of  primary  education  improved;  (ii)  access  and  participation  to  primary  education 
enhanced; and (iii) governance and management of primary education system improved. The 
total cost for the program is $14.7 billion, with $500 million financed by a concessional loan from 
ADB. The program was approved in September 2018, and an advance financing of $65 million 
was disbursed in December 2018. Additional $60 million was disbursed in June 2019 on the 
achievement  of  four  prior  results.3   The  program  is  making  progress  to  achieve  2019 
disbursement-linked indicators (DLIs).  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The program will strengthen teaching-learning quality for children to acquire the essential 
grade level competencies stipulated in the curriculum. It will also improve governance and 
management  of  the  primary  education  system,  which  is  necessary  for  education  quality 
enhancement. To achieve these goals, the following areas need to be strengthened: (i) needs-
based Continuous Professional Development (CPD) for in-service teacher development, (ii) 
classroom  teaching  assessment  system  for  monitoring  teaching  quality,  and  (iii)  education 
management  information  system  (EMIS)  for  monitoring  and  accountability.  The  proposed 
transaction technical assistance (TA) of $1.2 million, to be financed (on a grant basis) by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR), will support implementation of these innovative 
initiatives  in  the  initial  stage  of  the  program.4 The  TA  activities  include  (i)  supporting  the 
operationalization of  CPD framework (with an integrated component of ICT-based teacher 
training), (ii) providing technical support to update classroom observation tool, and (iii) structuring 
the web-based integrated EMIS and conducting early-stage tests. The proposed scope and scale 
of these activities, including intensive collaboration between ministries and other development 
partners and access to international networks and experts, requires a transaction TA to ensure 
the successful implementation of the loan program.5 The program and TA align with ADB’s 
Strategy 2030, which calls for improving education.6

B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
3.  Output 1: CPD framework operationalization with ICT-based teacher training. The 
TA will support the operationalization of the CPD framework7, which takes a lifelong approach to 
train teachers (especially on subject content and pedagogy), by guiding the implementation and 
evaluation of teacher development programs. This includes a study based on a survey of 
teachers’ training needs and assessment of existing training system and capacity. The study will 
propose a plan to operationalize the CPD framework by supporting the incorporation of teacher 
needs, regular assessments of teachers’ classroom performances, and improving teachers’ 
classroom  practices  under  upgraded  academic  supervision  to  meet  teacher  competencies 
requirements.  The study will also support the integration of ICT for teacher training, which is part 
of the structure of CPD framework. Cost-effective options for online learning, including open 
source course management system such as Moodle, will be considered. The operationalization 
plan will be piloted in selected areas based on needs. The Japan International Cooperation 
Agency (JICA) and ADB will closely coordinate in the work related to mathematics subject. This 
TA output supports output 1 (quality of primary education) of the ongoing program. 
 
4.  Deliverables under this output will include: (i) survey report on teachers’ training needs, 
covering gender issues and analysis; (ii) operationalization plan for CPD framework piloted in 
selected areas; and (iii) technical inputs for the ICT platform for teacher training, composed of (a) 
online and offline training platform, which is open for incorporating digitized training modules and 
the e-teaching and learning materials and at least 50% of major users are women; (b) online and 
offline teacher assessment modules; and (c) database in line with the requirements on data 
formatting for teacher management information system. 
 
5.  Output 2: Updated classroom observation tool for monitoring teaching practices. 
The TA will support updating the classroom observation tool from 3-scale points (not good, 
average, fair) to at least 5-scale points (by adding “good” and “very good”) with scientifically 
developed scoring rubric method to reflect the multiple dimensions of requirements on teaching 
quality (including, but not limited to pedagogy, subject knowledge, student engagement, and 
classroom environment). The TA will support the improvement of the capacity of academic 
supervisors (mainly assistant upazila8 education officers, public training institute instructors, 
upazila resource center instructors, and headmasters). Pilot trainings on using the updated 
classroom  observation  tool  will  be  provided  to  the  academic  supervisors  in  representative 
schools. This TA output supports output 1 (quality of primary education) of the ongoing program. 
 
6.  Deliverables under Output 2 will include: (i) sample survey of selected upazilas and 
schools for classroom observations, with sex-disaggregated data collected and gender analysis 
conducted; (ii) updated classroom observation tool from the current 3-scale points to at least 5-
scale points reflecting multiple dimensions on teaching quality; (iii) training on using the updated 
classroom observation tool conducted for selected academic supervisors, with at least 50% of 
teachers trained as women; (iv) outline of training program on academic supervision; (v) teacher 
monitoring and mentoring guidelines; and (vi) technical inputs for a sample database of teaching 
practices at selected upazilas. 
 
7.  Output 3: Piloting of web-based integrated EMIS and ICT platform for teacher 
training. The TA will support piloting the EMIS to systematically manage and report on the data 
 
7  A CPD framework has been drafted in June 2019 and is being finalized by the government. 
8  Upazila is an administrative region in Bangladesh. They function as sub-units of districts. Bangladesh has 492 
upazilas under 64 districts as of December 2017.

3 
on students, teachers, properties, trainings, textbooks, assessments and examinations, and 
school census. Online dashboards will be structured and piloted to meet the demands for data 
from major users at different levels. The TA will support early-stage tests to make sure the sub-
data systems conform to common database languages. The TA will also provide support to 
structure and pilot the ICT platform for teacher training. This TA output supports output 3 
(governance and management of primary education system) of the ongoing program. 
 
8.  The deliverables under Output 3 will include: (i) prototype online dashboards for realizing 
major M&E functions for users at different levels; (ii) early test reports with clients’ endorsement; 
(iii) detailed documentation of shared open codes for integrated database and for dashboards for 
future development purposes; and (iv) ICT teacher training platform piloted for incorporating 
digitized training modules and the e-teaching and learning materials, for which at least 50% of 
major users are women. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,200,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
JFPR and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
10.  Ineligible expenditures under the JFPR include (i) vehicle purchases, (ii) civil servant 
salaries, (iii) foreign travel, (iv) scholarships or long internships, (v) detailed engineering design, 
(vi) civil works and other related expenses, and (vii) those under ADB’s List of Ineligible Items (or 
Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities List.9 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The Ministry of Primary and Mass Education will be the executing agency and  the 
Directorate of Primary Education will be the implementing agency. The Human and Social 
Development  Division  of  ADB  South  Asia  Department  will  administer  the  TA.  It  will  be 
implemented from January 2020 to January 2022 and will be coordinated with other development 
partners. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

12.  Consulting services.  ADB will recruit three firms. Firms will be selected to ensure 
maximum quality for specialized services using a simplified technical proposal for the quality- and 
cost- based selection (QCBS) method (quality-cost ratio of 90:10). The first consulting firm will be 
a specialist with international expertise in primary education and will focus on materializing the 
CPD framework, including ICT for teacher training. This firm will prepare a CPD operationalization 
plan and pilot the operationalization. The second firm will be a specialist with international 
expertise in teacher assessment. This firm will review, update and pilot the classroom observation 
tool  for  application.  It  will  make  recommendations  to  improve  the  capacity  of  academic 
supervisors. The training on using the updated classroom observation tool will be provided to the 
academic supervisors. The third firm will be a specialist in establishing modern information 
system. The firm will provide technical support to structure the EMIS and conduct early-stage 
tests to make sure the sub-data systems conform to common database languages, and also pilot 
the major online dashboards that will meet the demands for data from major users at different 
levels. The firm will also pilot the ICT platform for teacher training.  
 
13.  ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  following  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as 
amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.10 Any training to be provided under the TA will be managed by consultants or directly 
procured by ADB in line with the ADB Procurement Policy and relevant staff Instructions.11 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,200,000 to the Government of Bangladesh to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund 
for Poverty Reduction for Support to Quality Enhancement in Primary Education, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
